The faith-based shareholders’ proposal was challenged by UnitedHealth twice, thanks to a recent SEC guidance change the shareholders slammed as unfair. They could still reintroduce it next year.

UnitedHealth (UNH), Humana (HUM), and CVS Health (CVS) rally in extended-hours trading on news that the US government will pay more than previously proposed to Medicare Advantage providers. Julie Hyman breaks down the details on Market Domination Overtime. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime here.

Medicare-focused insurer Humana led gains with a 16% jump, while other health insurers including UnitedHealth Group, Centene and CVS Health advanced between 5% and 10%.  The 5.06% average increase, more than double what the government proposed in January, could help profit margins in the sector after a post-COVID surge in demand for medical procedures drove up costs.
UnitedHealth Group (UNH) closed at $524.70 in the latest trading session, marking a -0.07% move from the prior day.
Medicare Advantage plans are paid more for sicker members and less for healthier members, which provides an incentive for MA plans to report as many diagnoses as legitimately possible.
Shares of health insurance operators surged Tuesday after the government said it would pay a higher rate to Medicare insurers than previously estimated.

The Trump administration just rescued the big health insurers with a $25 billion payout.  For more than a year, the story for these companies has been that the business of privately managing Medicare plans had become a major disappointment.  U.S. seniors were seeking lots of medical care, eating away at insurers’ profits.
